It would be ideal if this tool were visual and didn't involve writing velocity macros.

fields.description:
Currently "Original Estimation" field cannot be edited if any work is logged against the issue.

An option of allowing to edit this field after work logging would be expected.

Business case:
Let's assume that work was started and logged against the issue, and than requirements are changing. Original estimation cannot be updated but in real is different than entered with previous requirements. Than, when you want to compare real time spent on issue vs. estimated - there is no sense to do it.
fields.summary: Allowing to edit "Original Estimation" field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19644].
  {panel}

This feature was removed per http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-15660

I have tried to use the setting set to false and true and see no change.

Steps to reproduce

Edit the C:\a\JIRA-Enterprise-3.13.4\atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\jira-application.properties and add the following line to the very end of the file

jira.option.bulk.send.notifications=false

Restart JIRA
Perform a bulk edit
See that the box is checked and slam head on desk.

I repeated the same to see if by setting it to "true" I would have success. The same behavior was seen.

Is there a workaround to have the default behavior of bulk edits not to notify folks via email? Is there another setting we can use in jira-application.properties or another properties file that could turn off email notifications for bulk edits? I appreciate any help in this matter.
fields.summary: The default setting for Bulk Operations is set to "Send Email for this Update".  We would like to change the default setting to "Not send email for this update" instead of having to uncheck the silly box every single time we perform bulk operations

fields.description:
Hi guys,
I tried raising a support request for this but they firmly but kindly told me it wasn't their problem!  I've set up a change control workflow which people are now using but that I've now realised has a bug - if changes are 're-opened', approvers who approved changes the first time round can't re-approve them.

The basic question is - is there a way of preventing a use from making a workflow transition when I have their username / userid stored in a custom field?  Sounds so simple, but I can't seem to do it.

The issue is described in much more detail below for those with the patience - a resolution would be very much appreciated!!

Edmund. 
------------------------------

> Hi guys,
> Essentially, we have set up a workflow that doesn't work, but we've only just realised it and it's now being used which is why I've said it is impacting the business.
> I want a way of being able to prevent a user from performing a workflow transition when their username is stored in a custom field.  This is to do with an approval system - we have issues that require any three people from a group of 10 to approve something and we don't want the same person to approve it more than once.
> I was happy that we'd solved this using the 'JIRA Misc Workflow Extensions' plugin.  This has a 'Separation of Duties Condition' module that allows me to stop someone performing a workflow transition if they have previously moved the workflow from one state to another.  I used it to say 'if user has previously moved workflow from status 'pending approval' to status 'pending approval' (ie. if they were the first or second approver), don't let them make this second (or third and final) approval step.  
> This worked well, but what I forgot to think about is that post approval, a change can be re-opened for various reasons, forcing people to change details and submit it for approval again.  I now find that approvers who have previously approved a change can no longer re-approve it.
> A work around is to force people to clone changes rather than re-approve them, but this means we lose the change history.
> I actually think it should be a very simple thing to do.  When someone performs a workflow transition, put their username (using the %%CURRENT_USER%% function / variable) into a custom field.  I then just need to check the second time round that their user name isn't in the 'first approver' custom field.
> I've tried to do this using the 'Value Field' condition.  ie. User can only perform a second approval if 'Approver 1' custom field != %%CURRENT_USER%%, but this doesn't work.  I think the 'Value Field' condition can't be compatible with %%CURRENT_USER%% (ie. I guess it just sees the string %%CURRENT_USER%% rather than a variable) - is this the case?  
> There is another condition, called 'User is in Custom Field', using which I can force only the person who approved the first time to be able to approve the second time, so it seems the logic is really simple!  It's just that I need the reverse of this - ie. the ability in the list of conditions to say 'and NOT this condition', but I can't seem to do that either.
> If you could show me how to achieve this, you'd help sort what's becoming quite a reasonably big problem for me!  

> Many thanks,
> Edmund Heyes.
fields.summary: How to stop a user performing a workflow transition using the fact their userid is stored in a custom field

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19638].
  {panel}

There is currently no way of accessing the gadget-editing window via keyboard until the gadget header icons are made visible by mousing over the header. Once the mouse is over the header, everything except moving the gadget around the dashboard is available via keyboard.

Possible resolutions include:
* an option to make gadget menu icons always visible
* a hidden element in the gadget header that can receive focus, at which point the icons become visible and available (the hidden element should be "visible" to screen readers)
fields.summary: access gadget editing controls/menu via keyboard

(x) IE 7
(/) IE 8.0.7600.16385
(/) FF 3.0.14
(x) FF 3.5.4

This is especially problematic for users of Vimperator, and from an accessibility standpoint, as all navigation is performed via keyboard.
fields.summary: page loads into gadget frame when executing links with keyboard in FF 3.5 and IE7

fields.description:
So often times in support we have users who create issues because they are having performance problems. One of the first things I look for are any third party plugins the user may have installed. It would save a lot of time if in the system information could distinguish what the User added vs. what is installed by default. This was a lot easier in the past because we generally just had "Atlassian" plugins installed by default. However, now with JQL and Gadgets, it seems there are non Atlassian plugins installed by default. Can we please have some separation in the system information so that we can tell the difference between default and non default plugins faster. My current workaround is to have a text document with the default plugins from a clean instance, then make a new text document with the clients system information for each case. I then diff the files. Can we please implement this feature for support.

Cheers,
Jon
fields.summary: Distinguish default plugins from user installed plugins.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce on IE:

# Set up JIRA to have multiple tabs on the edit screen
# Edit an issue
# Change the value of a field, switch tabs

This does not happen using Firefox. The dialog should not be shown as the user isn't technically navigating away from the page - the link that they click on the tab invokes {{javascript:showTab()}}, which just controls which DIV is visible, so the dirty form data is still kept. I'm guessing that maybe Internet Explorer interprets this as navigating away since the javascript is in the {{href}} and not in an {{onclick}} event.
fields.summary: Switching between tabs after editing a field on IE causes the "Are you sure you want to navigate away" popup dialog box to appear every time

fields.description:
In Jira 3.13.5 there was no email notification when creating users through the SOAP interface. Jira 4.0 does send them. This may be problematic, specially when Jira is integrated with external user management systems like LDAP, where the passwords are stored in their repositories. The SOAP request cannot be created with the real password, and the password field cannot be left blank.

Ideally, the SOAP request would have a new parameter where to indicate whether an email notification should be triggered.

A second best alternative is to go back to 3.13.5 functionality, where no notifications where triggered.
fields.summary: SOAP interface sends 'account created' email for createUser method

	at com.atlassian.jira.web.monitor.ActiveRequestsFilter$PassToChainFilterFunc.doFilter(ActiveRequestsFilter.java:346)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.monitor.ActiveRequestsFilter$DebugLogFilterFunc.doFilter(ActiveRequestsFilter.java:463)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.monitor.ActiveRequestsFilter.doFilter(ActiveRequestsFilter.java:173)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:235)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:206)
	at com.atlassian.jira.startup.JiraStartupChecklistFilter.doFilter(JiraStartupChecklistFilter.java:75)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:235)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:206)
	at com.atlassian.multitenant.servlet.MultiTenantServletFilter.doFilter(MultiTenantServletFilter.java:91)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:235)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:206)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.filters.steps.ChainedFilterStepRunner.doFilter(ChainedFilterStepRunner.java:74)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:235)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:206)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke(StandardWrapperValve.java:233)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContextValve.invoke(StandardContextValve.java:191)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.invoke(StandardHostValve.java:127)
	at org.apache.catalina.valves.ErrorReportValve.invoke(ErrorReportValve.java:102)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardEngineValve.invoke(StandardEngineValve.java:109)
	at org.apache.catalina.valves.AccessLogValve.invoke(AccessLogValve.java:554)
	at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteAdapter.service(CoyoteAdapter.java:298)
	at org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11AprProcessor.process(Http11AprProcessor.java:864)
	at org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11AprProtocol$Http11ConnectionHandler.process(Http11AprProtocol.java:579)
	at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.AprEndpoint$Worker.run(AprEndpoint.java:1665)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:662)
Caused by: java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
{noformat}

h5. Cause

The concrete implementation of IssueSecurityLevelManager, IssueLevelSecurities uses a concurrent hash map to cache {project -> {user -> security_level}} for quicker access to security levels per project. The caching size is roughly #projects * #users * #security_levels. The security_level is actually copied each time it appears in the cache (i.e. if the "test" level is visible by 5 users, then there will be 5 copies of the level in the cache).

h5. Workaround

Reducing the use of the security scheme in this customer's case is the resolution, but otherwise Atlassian may need to look at refactoring the cache.
fields.summary: OutOfMemoryError caused by a large number of Issue Security Levels

fields.description:
When the HTML body of the *Text Gadget* reaches a certain length, the contents will fail to load and the *Edit* link disappears. h4. Steps to Reproduce: * Add the *Text Gadget* to your dashboard * Add a lot of content into the HTML body, for example: {code}
Milestone Date Tickets
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153
Milestone mark 1 9/15 49/153

 

{code} * Save the gadget, it will appear just fine initially * Refresh the page * Notice that the gadget is blank and there is no option to *Edit* it h4. Cause When refreshing the gadget, it actually performs a request containing all of the HTML body. So the more data you've added, the longer the request becomes. At a certain point, you'll hit the limit of the request, either on the web browser side, the proxy side, or the web server side. h4. Workaround if Head Request Limitation is caused by Tomcat In _server.xml_: * Try increasing the *maxHttpHeaderSize* ** by default it is set to 8192 kb. * For example, here's the default connector: {code} {code} * This can be modified to be: {code} {code} * Restart JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19607].
  {panel}

The AttachFile tag currently does not have the *Attached By* attribute. 

This attribute would be very useful when importing data into JIRA, where there is a different author of each attachment (this is a normal case when migrating projects from a different issue tracking system).

Currently JIRA sets this field to user who run the script - which is not always true.

The problem is that this *Attached By* field cannot be changed easily.
fields.summary: Allow AttachFile jelly tag to specify the "Attached By" attribute for an attachment

fields.description:
Creating on behalf of the customer:
{quote}
If a successfully bulk change was made and the user clicks the browser back button, the following error message is displayed:
'Your session has timed out
Your session timed out while you were in the process of selecting issues to perform a bulk operation on. This means that we have lost the information that we collected thus far from the wizard. You will need to try the bulk operation again from the start. Sorry for the inconvenience.'

This is a very misleading message for users because neither the session timed out nor any information was lost.

Steps to reproduce:

    * Go to 'Find Issues'
    * Click 'View' to view some issues
    * Do a bulk change
    * Do it until the end (the type of change doesn't matter)
    * If the bulk change has successfully finished, click the browser's back button
    * Click "Resend" if asked.
    * The message will appear
{quote}
fields.summary: Wrong Error Message when pressing Browser Back-Button after Bulk-Change

I understand it may take a bit to render the search results, but while I am waiting (upwards of 5 minutes), my workstation is almost entirely consumed with this task. See attached screenshot showing firefox at 99% CPU.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19589].
  {panel}

I request that the filterpicker.jsp and the managefilters.jsp not populate the issue count on the server side and instead return the page without the issue count and have it filled in later asynchronously like the Favorite Filters portlet in Jira 3.13.

I've cloned this from JRA-16959 which was resolved as a duplicate.  I agree that the Favourite Filters portlet performs well as of 3.13.  

The ManageFilters screen and the FilterPickerPopup window launched from portlet configuration are still very slow.  Our Manage Filters screen takes about 15 seconds to load. It takes about 45 seconds to load the My tab in Manage Filters. The Filter Picker Popup takes about 15 seconds to load as well...until I disabled the issue count column in the JSP...after which it loads instantly.

And in JRA-8106, Vincent notes that he encounters similar some performance problems with Issue Filer Management which are not related to JRA-16959. He writes, {quote} In our instance, as Administrator, I am able to see many Filters (8 filters per Project and more than 200 projects).
Due to theses figures, in JIRA 3.10, I did use any more the Filter Portlet.
Since JIRA 3.13.x, I encounter the same performance problems, for the Portlet (normal !) but also for the ManageFilters page.
It appears a priori that each filter is systematically executed in order to provide the Issue count.

May we consider an enhancement of these two features (Portlet and ManageFilters page), where Issue count are calculated periodically and stored in order to have the figures as estimate values, but not systematically recalculated. {quote}
fields.summary: Bad Performance due to Issue Count recalculation in ManageFilters and FilterPickerPopUp

fields.description: The JIRA FishEye Plugin's build process relies on the {{jira-subproject-plugins pom}} and the {{jira-rest-plugin}}, so in order to keep the plugin's 4.0.x compatible build running against the latest SNAPSHOT, we need to run a deploy of the {{jira-subproject-plugins}} project when the atlassian-jira SNAPSHOT is published.

fields.description:
The Watched Issues/Voted Issues Portlets (or is it now Gadgets) on the default Dashboard allow the columns displayed to be configured.

For the Watched Issues, when the "Default Columns" and another column (I wanted to display Status as well) are both selected (using the CTRL button), only the "other" column (eg, Status) is displayed on the Dashboard.

However, for Voted Issues, when the "Default Columns" and another column (I wanted to display Status as well) are both selected (using the CTRL button), the "Default Columns" _and_ the "other" column (eg, Status) are displayed on the Dashboard.

The behaviour should be consistent.

Personally, I like the Voted Issues behaviour - less work for the user (which should always be the goal).

This is repeatable.

fields.description:
An "empty" search request (returning all issues) can sometimes be represented like this in the pre-4.0 XML:

{code}
<SearchRequest id="10147" name="x" author="xxx" description="xxxxxxxxxxx" user="xxx" favCount="0">
<request>
<![CDATA[<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<searchrequest name='x'/>
]]>
</request>
</SearchRequest>
{code}

i.e. no SearchParameters and no Sorts.

fields.description:
Activity streams are great !
They could get better with the introduction of hierarchical activity streams :-)

The way that most JIRA instances get configured are (from what I know)

Projects -> (Versions, Components) -> Parent Issues -> Subtask issues -> (Worklog, Commits, Comments & Edits)

For instance if I'm looking at a certain parent issue (such as a story), I would like to see all activity related to that issue, including the subtasks.  

If I'm looking at a version (or component) I'm interested in what has happened with that version.
Currently the activity stream either shows to much (like in the activity stream gadget) or too little (like in the activity stream panel of an issue).

It might be an idea to base the activity stream on a filter (?)
fields.summary: Hierarchical activity streams

fields.description:
Hi,

This seems to be a bug with JIRA: I added 2 "Select List" custom fields to the "Resolve Issue" screen for a group of projects. For each field, I created two contexts, because one of the projects requires a different set of options. In both fields, I set default values for the second context, but the problem is that the default value is not automatically selected in the "Resolve Issue" screen.

The funny thing is that I have another "Select List" field in the same screen; this field is configured only with the default context, and also has a default value set, which is automatically selected when I enter the screen. Looks like the issue is present only when a custom field has more than one context.

Please take a look at the attached document, which contains screenshots describing the issue with more detail. Have you ever detected this behavior? Is this something that might have been solved in newer versions of JIRA? This turned to be a little critical for me, because I was working on a request to set default values for the two fields described above (as the easiest approach), and it's getting more difficult than normal.

Thanks in advance for your comments,
GERMAN
fields.summary: Default value not displayed in "Select List" field with two contexts

I propose one of the following enhancements, to avoid this:

** My Favourite Dashboard 1
** My Favourite Dashboard 2

** System Dashboard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19568].
  {panel}

secure/admin/jira/ViewApplicationProperties.jspa
secure/admin/jira/EditApplicationProperties!default.jspa

These are two separate web pages with completely different layouts. It would be helpful to have 1 webpage instead of two, so you can make changes more directly. This is such a core part of site administration, please improve its usability.

Have something (button or checkbox), either for the whole page, or for each section, or for each item, to enable editing the configuration, so that you have to deliberately make changes, and prevent an accidental change by clicking on something by mistake.

When you are making changes, keep track of which items have been changed, and highlight them. It should be easy to verify that I have changed exactly one setting.

The help text (which only shows up on the edit page) should be toggle-able somehow, so it doesn't clutter up the page when you know what you're doing. On the other hand, you shouldn't have to go to the edit page just to see the help text. Allow me to turn it on or off if I need it. And maybe force it to be visible when you are editing a particular item.
fields.summary: combine display + edit pages of General Configuration

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19567].
  {panel}

Here's what I see under Global settings:
============
Attachments
Bamboo Servers
CVS Modules
System Dashboard
Events
FishEye Configuration
Perforce Job Integration
General Configuration
Global Permissions
Issue Linking
Look and Feel
Mail Servers
Sub-Tasks
Time Tracking
Trackbacks
User Defaults
Workflows
GreenHopper

It's not in alphabetical order; therefore you have some way (maybe this is just hardcoded HTML?) of ordering it to your liking. The current ordering is really awful because you have to scan through all these lists to find what you think you need. I would suggest the following:

General Configuration

Attachments
Dashboard (rename from System Dashboard)
Events
Global Permissions
Issue Linking
Look and Feel
Mail Servers
Sub-Tasks
Time Tracking
Trackbacks
User Defaults
Workflows

Bamboo Servers
CVS Modules
FishEye Configuration
GreenHopper
Perforce Job Integration

======

1. Separate global configuration. That's the most important menu to find, it should be *really* obvious how to find it.
2. Separate out the optional modules.
3. This gives you 3 groups, put all the items in alphabetical order.
fields.summary: reorganize "global settings" area of Administration to make it more usable

fields.description:
h3. Symptom

When creating a JIRA issue, a NullPointException is generated.

The following appears within {{atlassian-jira.log}}:

{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.SimpleWorkflowManager.isEditable(SimpleWorkflowManager.java:520)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.managers.DefaultIssueManager.isEditable(DefaultIssueManager.java:379)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at com.atlassian.util.profiling.object.ObjectProfiler.profiledInvoke(ObjectProfiler.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.jira.config.component.SwitchingInvocationHandler.invoke(SwitchingInvocationHandler.java:28)
	at $Proxy38.isEditable(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.osgi.hostcomponents.impl.DefaultComponentRegistrar$ContextClassLoaderSettingInvocationHandler.invoke(DefaultComponentRegistrar.java:129)
	at $Proxy38.isEditable(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.osgi.bridge.external.HostComponentFactoryBean$DynamicServiceInvocationHandler.invoke(HostComponentFactoryBean.java:150)
	at $Proxy38.isEditable(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.jira.toolkit.customfield.NullCFType.getVelocityParameters(NullCFType.java:51)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.customfields.CustomFieldUtils.buildParams(CustomFieldUtils.java:408)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugin.customfield.CustomFieldTypeModuleDescriptor.getEditHtml(CustomFieldTypeModuleDescriptor.java:86)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.getEditHtml(CustomFieldImpl.java:897)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.getCreateHtml(CustomFieldImpl.java:883)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.getCreateHtml(CustomFieldImpl.java:878)
{noformat}

And the below may also be present:

{noformat}
2012-08-18 15:49:27,711 http-8080-9 ERROR      [500ErrorPage.jsp] Exception caught in 500 page null
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.OSWorkflowManager.isEditable(OSWorkflowManager.java:1077)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.managers.DefaultIssueManager.isEditable(DefaultIssueManager.java:464)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor563.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source)
{noformat}

h3. Cause

The {{SimpleWorkflowManager.isEditable}} or {{OSWorkflowManager.isEditable}} methods can throw a NPE when called with an issue without a status. The most common way for this to occur is for a custom field to call this method on the 'Create Issue' screen (i.e. before the issue is associated with a workflow).

For example, the supporttools (i.e. NullCFType) field from the [JIRA Toolkit|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.jira.toolkit] plugin does this.

h3. Workaround

# Delete the Support Tools Bar custom field under *Administration > Custom Fields*.
# Disable the Support Tool Bar ({{supporttools}}) module under *Administration > Plugins* > JIRA Toolkit Plugin > expand the modules enabled section.
fields.summary: The 'SimpleWorkflowManager.isEditable' method can throw a NPE when called with an issue without a status.

fields.description:
Hi guys,
A request.  Is there a way I can notify someone (via a notification scheme) when an issue is commented on but only when it is in a certain status?

My example is someone raising a change - they create the change, it gets commented on various times, and then they submit it for approval.  Several people need to approve the change, and whilst it is in the Pending Approval stage I would like to notify these change approvers of any extra comments, since someone who has approved a change could change their mind and reject it depending on a comment (whilst not having emailed them on the previous comments).  

I thought that I could hide the 'Comment' button from the 'Operations' list and create a workflow Comment button instead.  I could use workflow conditions to have two Comment buttons with only one shown depending on the status.

The problem is, of course, that my only way of removing the Operations 'Comment' is by removing permission to comment, which then destroys my workflow 'Comment' buttons.  So I have to live with having an Operations Comment button and a workflow action Comment button at the same time, which is confusing to the user.

Any hints and tips would be appreciated.  My workaround is to call the Workflow Action Comment 'Comment and Notify Approvers' so hopefully users can surmise the difference.
fields.summary: Notification dependent on task status

fields.description:
Our team recently migrated from Bugzilla to JIRA and now we are missing a nice little feature of our bugzilla clunker. ;-)

When writing a comment on an issue in Bugzilla it is possible to refer to another issue or even to a specific comment of another issue or to a another comment of the same issue by writing:

{code}There is something remarkable in bug1234comment2 to consider...{code}

This becomes ("There is something remarkable in +bug1234comment2+ to consider...") a link to comment #2 of ticket 1234.

Or even shorter:

{code}...as said in comment3 we have to...{code}

This becomes ("...as said in +comment3+ we have to...") a link to comment #3 of the same ticket as the new comment.

One part of this feature is already available, JIRA does create links when it detectes a issue key within a comment. But for linking to another comment i have to use a cumbersome 'Permalink'.

It is a little bit hard to explain the usage of permalinks to the users when they are used to the easy way of linking offered by Bugzilla. I (as JIRA admin) had been asked to add comment numbers to all comments so it would be possible to refer to other comments by their number. :(
fields.summary: Easy way of linking from one comment to another

Raised from a support request from a customer

We normally specify a defect as fixed in a particular build of a version of the project.
We have created custom field in the create defect screen to display the build number; but it requires to be pre-populated in the Project Admin screen where we add the components and versions.

1. We need to add builds under every version in the Project Admin screen.
2. This build numbers should be accessible to multiple custom fields. (eg., Reporter build, Confirmer Build and Resolver build)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19533].
  {panel}

When your operating system has its timezone set to "Brazil" or "America/Sao_Paolo" or "GMT-3", there is a peculiarity in Javascript whereby the following happens:

Evaluating
{{javascript:document.innerHTML=new Date(2009,09,17)}}
produces the output
bq. Sat Oct 17 2009 00:00:00 GMT-0300 (BRT)

and

evaluating
{{javascript:document.innerHTML=new Date(2009,09,18)}}
produces the output
bq. Sat Oct 17 2009 23:00:00 GMT-0300 (BRT)

This is causing a bug in our calendar popup picker used for dates in JIRA, where for instance in 2009, the 17th of October is repeated twice, as shown in the screenshot. The problem repeats every October.

Similar problems could exist with other timezones and months. Brazil is different from Australia in that DST takes effect at Midnight.

The problem with the date picker only occurs when:
* The time component is set to Midnight (i.e. its a date-only picker, or a date-time picker with the time set to Midnight)
* There is already a value set for the component
fields.summary: Calendar popup prints multiple dates in October when client is on Brazilian timezone

- create saved filter based on JQL: assignee = currentUser() order by priority desc

This appears to happen for any order by clause you use. I believe this only happens with saved filters.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19529].
  {panel}

JIRA now ships with bundled plugins that have translations of their own, separate from those in JiraWebActionSupport.properties

For instance, the dashboard has "Add Gadget". If you want to translate then you need to

- unzip the file WEB-INF/classes/com/atlassian/jira/plugin/atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip
- figure out which plugin owns the string you want to translate
- unjar the jar
- add your translations
- re-jar the plugin
- rezip the bundled-plugins.zip
- start JIRA and see if it worked

We don't document this anywhere right now.
fields.summary: Need to document how to translate bundled plugins
